Cylas formicarius, commonly known as the sweetpotato weevil, is a species of beetle that belongs to the family Brentidae. It is considered a major pest of sweetpotato (Ipomoea batatas) crops, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions.

The Cylas formicarius is a small, elongated beetle, measuring around 5-7 millimeters in length. It has a distinctive, ants-like appearance with a long, slender snout, a brown or black body, and reddish-brown or black legs. The adults are typically active during the day and feed on the leaves, stems, and tubers of the sweetpotato plant.

The life cycle of the sweetpotato weevil begins with the female laying eggs on the surface of the sweetpotato plant, often in the stem or tuber. The larvae hatch and burrow into the plant, feeding on the internal tissues and causing significant damage to the crop. The larvae then pupate within the plant before emerging as adult beetles, completing the life cycle.

The Cylas formicarius is a major concern for sweetpotato farmers, as the damage caused by the larvae can lead to significant yield losses and reduce the quality of the harvested tubers. Effective management strategies, such as the use of resistant cultivars, crop rotation, and chemical or biological control methods, are essential for mitigating the impact of this pest on sweetpotato production.
